I'm curious as to how IQ scores come around. Is there some standardized test or something? All I can ever find online are those B.S. 20-30 questions where some people get 75 and others get 175.

Nope. Disregard any IQ claim you ever see. There's no reliable way to test it.

Most accurate IQ tests are made from about 60-80 questions. It takes about 2 -3 hours to complete them all, and you are under supervisor when filling them.

The final score is not based on 1question = +1IQ, but very strange, strange pattern. Like if I was wrong at question 1, you were wrong at question one, but checked different answer, we would have both different score.

Altough they will test you to what they think IQ currently means, which is very hard definition which changes from time to time, so the tests do too.

I wonder if we could get a break down of what precisely the QA phase is.

Being a software engineering student I think it means scenarios testing... unit testing... basically computer run testing of the code that's been added.

Then someone mentioned an experimental phase... this I think would be play testing. While the computer run testing can validate that the numbers they expect to get are what they are getting... play testing is needed to see if those numbers make the game more fun or are balanced or don't break other things..

So those are my guesses as to what they are doing. If previous updates can be used as a model then the update could be out in mere days. Or if they found something really wrong... and difficult to track down... it could take longer... much longer. Yeah! Testing!

From what I remember when I did testing:

- QA: all branches merged, KSP is very unstable (as in "won't start with fresh install on some machines"), lots of bugfixes and versions. Those are similar to "beta-testing" in release cycles.

- Experimentals: after QA, much less bugs, but still some gameplay fixes needed (less obvious; those appear in uncommon scenarios). Those are Release Candidates.

So basically, QA is to remove all show-stopper bugs, and experimentals to track/fix gameplay bugs.
